chapter.fullItemName: Scenario: UTI with catheter  no haematuria
chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Suspected urinary tract infection without haematuria in non-pregnant women with an indwelling urinary catheter
chapter.summary: Covers the management of lower urinary tract infection in non-pregnant women with an indwelling urinary catheter.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage non-pregnant catheterized women with suspected urinary tract infection not associated with haematuria?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange urgent assessment in secondary care if:
    • There are any features of serious or systemic illness such as sepsis, pyelonephritis or if the woman is dehydrated or unable to tolerate oral fluids and drugs.
    • For further information, see the CKS topic on Pyelonephritis - acute.
  • Refer/seek specialist advice if the woman:
    • Has a higher risk of developing complications (for example has structural or functional abnormalities or a comorbid condition such as immunosuppression).
    • Has recurrent catheter associated-UTI (CAUTI).
    • Has infection caused by atypical or resistant bacteria.
    • Has suspected cancer — arrange an urgent 2-week wait referral.
      • For more information, see the CKS topics on Urological cancers - recognition and referral and Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.
  • Advise the woman on self-care measures:
    • Simple analgesia such as paracetamol can be used for pain relief.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain.
    • Encourage intake of enough fluids to avoid dehydration.
      • Do not recommend cranberry products or urine alkalinising agents in the treatment of lower UTI.
    • Patient information leaflets ‘Treating your infection – Urinary tract infection (UTI)’ and ‘Urinary tract infections: A leaflet for older adults and carers’ are available from the Royal Collage of General Practice website.
  • If the catheter has been in place for more than 7 days:
    • Check for blockage and consider removing the catheter or, if this cannot be done, changing it as soon as possible — do not delay antibiotic treatment in the interim.
    • Before antibiotics are taken send a sample from mid-stream urine if the catheter has been removed or from the new catheter if changed — ensure the laboratory are aware of previous antibiotic use and that this is a suspected catheter associated UTI.
  • Offer an antibiotic:
    • Take account of severity of symptoms, risk of developing complications, previous urine culture and susceptibility results, previous antibiotic use, and local antimicrobial resistance data.
    • First-choice oral antibiotic (for lower UTI symptoms only):
      • Nitrofurantoin (if eGFR ≥45ml/minute) 100mg modified-release twice a day for 7 days.
      • Trimethoprim (if low risk of resistance) 200mg twice a day for 7 days.
      • Amoxicillin (only if culture results available and susceptible) 500mg three times a day for 7 days.
    • Second-choice (for lower UTI symptoms only, when first-choice unsuitable):
      • Pivmecillinam (a penicillin) 400mg initial dose, then 200mg three times a day for a total of 7 days.
    • Be aware that nitrofurantoin and pivmecillinam are only licensed for uncomplicated lower UTIs, and are not suitable for people with upper UTI symptoms or a blocked catheter.
    • A summary of the National Institute for Health and Care (NICE) antimicrobial prescribing guidance is available on the NICE website.
  • Advise all women to seek urgent medical review if:
    • Symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly at any time or fail to improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics — consider the possibility of alternative or serious diagnoses such as pyelonephritis or sepsis.
    • Send a urine sample for culture and susceptibility testing (if this has not already been done) and consider treatment with another agent (as described above) while awaiting sensitivities.
  • Follow up urine culture and susceptibility results:
    • Review the choice of antibiotic when results are available.
    • Change the antibiotic according to susceptibility results if bacteria are resistant using narrow-spectrum antibiotics if possible.
  • Ensure good practice in the management of long-term urinary catheters:
    • Regularly assess the need for catheterisation — urinary catheterisation should be carried out by appropriately trained healthcare workers using aseptic technique.
    • Do not routinely offer antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent catheter-associated UTIs when changing catheters in women with a long-term indwelling urinary catheter.
      • Prophylaxis may be appropriate in certain cases for example history of UTI following catheter change — discuss with a specialist.
    • Do not routinely treat catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of catheter associated UTI (CA-UTI) are based on the clinical guidelines Healthcare-associated infections: prevention and control in primary and community care [NICE, 2017c], Catheter associated urinary tract infections: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2018c], Diagnosis of urinary tract infections (UTIs). Quick reference guide for primary care: for consultation and local adaptation [PHE, 2017], and Urological infections [EAU, 2018] and expert opinion in a review article [Johnston, 2017].

Urgent assessment

Clinical guidelines from Public Health England (PHE) [PHE, 2017] and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2018c] highlight the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of serious illness such as pyelonephritis and sepsis.

Referral/seeking specialist advice

The recommendations on when to refer/seek specialist advice on further management of CA-UTI are based on the NICE guidelines Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2017b] and Catheter associated urinary tract infections: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2018c].

  • CA-UTIs are often polymicrobial and multiple-drug resistant [EAU, 2018].
Self-care measures

Recommendations on use of simple analgesia, maintaining adequate hydration and advice on prevention of further UTI are based on clinical guidance from PHE [PHE, 2017] and NICE [NICE, 2018c; NICE, 2018d].

  • NICE found no evidence to support the use of cranberry products and urine alkalinising agents in treatment of lower UTI [NICE, 2018d].
Change/removal of catheter

The recommendation on considering removing or changing a urinary catheter when CA-UTI is suspected is based on the NICE clinical guideline Catheter associated urinary tract infections: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2018c] and guidance from PHE [PHE, 2017] and The European Association of Urology (EAU) [EAU, 2018].

  • A urine sample complete with detailed clinical information should be sent for culture and sensitivities [PHE, 2017; NICE, 2018c].
Antibiotic treatment

The recommendations on antibiotic choice and duration are from the NICE guideline Catheter associated urinary tract infections: antimicrobial prescribing [NICE, 2018c].

  • Clinical guidance from PHE [PHE, 2017], EAU [EAU, 2018] and NICE [NICE, 2018c] agree on the need to take a urine culture prior to initiating antibiotics due to the wide variety of possible infecting organisms, potential for multi-organism infection and increased risk of antimicrobial resistance associated with CA-UTI.
  • A lower risk of resistance to the prescribed antibiotic is likely if it has not been used in the preceding 3 months, previous urine culture suggests susceptibility (but this was not used), and when used in younger people in areas where local epidemiology data suggest resistance is low. A higher risk of resistance is likely with recent use and in older people in long term care facilities [NICE, 2018c].
Advice on seeking review

Guidance from PHE [PHE, 2017] and NICE [NICE, 2018d] advises that the woman should be advised to seek urgent medical review if symptoms worsen at any time or fail to improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics.

  • On review the possibility of alternative or serious diagnoses such as pyelonephritis or sepsis should be considered.
Follow up urine culture and susceptibility results 
  • Guidance from NICE [NICE, 2018c] and PHE [PHE, 2017] recommends that choice of antibiotic is reviewed when culture results become available – antibiotic should be changed according to susceptibility results if bacteria are resistant, using narrow-spectrum antibiotics wherever possible.
Management of urinary catheters

The recommendations on management of short-term or long-term (indwelling or intermittent) urinary catheters are based on clinical guidelines from NICE on Healthcare Associated Infection [NICE, 2017c] and international guidelines from the American Association of Urology [AUA, 2014] and the European Association of Urology [EAU, 2018].

  • Do not use prophylactic antibiotics to prevent catheter-associated UTIs [EAU, 2018; NICE, 2018c] — seek specialist advice for recurrent CA-UTI.
  • Do not treat catheter-associated asymptomatic bacteriuria in general — the longer a catheter is in place, the more likely bacteriuria will be present.  Nearly all people who are catheterised will have bacteriuria after 1 month. Antibiotic treatment is not routinely needed for asymptomatic bacteriuria in non-pregnant people with a catheter [EAU, 2018; NICE, 2018c].
